byline.contributor: Jane Perlez reported from Beijing, and Javier C. Hernández from Hong Kong.
byline.original: By JANE PERLEZ and JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

abstract: United States briefs its Asian allies on plans to send ships through waters near man-made Chinese islands in South China Sea; so-called freedom of navigation patrols could be seen as aggressive response to Chinese claims on disputed area and escalate tensions between China and US; allies and experts express mixed enthusiasm and urge caution.
lead_paragraph: The moves, which would come within 12 nautical miles of at least one of a set of disputed islands, are meant to challenge China’s efforts to claim large parts of the waterway.

headline.main: U.S. Tells Asian Allies That Navy Will Patrol Near Islands in South China Sea
headline.print_headline: U.S. Tells Asian Allies That Navy Will Patrol Near Disputed Islands

snippet: The moves, which would come within 12 nautical miles of at least one of a set of disputed islands, are meant to challenge China’s efforts to claim large parts of the waterway.
